div.l: Aleyn answered Iohn wolt thou so
Than wolle I be beneth be my croun
And se howe the mele falles a doun
Into the trough that shalbe my desport
For Iohn in feith I may be of yoᵘur sort
Ay is as ille a Miller as is ye
This myller smyled of her nycete
And thought al this is don but for a wile
They wene that nomān may hem begile
But be my thrifte yet shalle I blere her ye
For al their sleyght and her philosophye
The more queynt crekes that they make
The more shalle I stele when I take
In stede of floure yet wolle I yeue hem brenne
The grettest clerkes benot wisest menne
As whilom the wolfe spake to the mare
Of alle her art ne counte I not atare
Out of the dore he goth fulle pryuely
Whan that he sawe his tyme softly
He loketh vp and doun tille he hath founde
Thyse clerkes hors where they stode bounde
Behynde the mylle vndir a lefselle
And to the hors he goth feire and welle
He stripeth of the bridille right anone
And when the hors were loos they gan gone
Taward the felde where wild marys renne
Fotth wᵗith wyhy through thyck and thynne
This Miller goth a geyne no worde he seyde
But doth note and with the clerkes pleyde
Tille that her corne was feire ⁊and welle grounde
And whenne the mele is sacked and bounde
This Iohn goth forth ⁊and fynt his hors aweye
And gan to cry harowe and welaweye
